Award.AwardTitle: Timed for a Successful Career: NSF/AWM Travel Grants for Women in the Mathematical Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Association for Women in Mathematics will administer the NSF-AWM Travel Grants Program for a three-year period. This program, which has run for over twenty years, supports the travel of women in the mathematical sciences who wish to actively participate in domestic or international research conferences, as well as longer-term visits to work with a mentor. Funding is allocated competitively, and allows approximately one hundred and forty-four regular travel grants and twenty-six mentoring grants to be awarded over the three-year period. Most of the funding is intended to benefit mathematical sciences research, but a portion of the travel grants will fund mathematics researchers to participate in mathematics education research conferences and mathematics education researchers to travel to mathematics conferences. A portion of the mentoring grants will foster communication between mathematicians and researchers in mathematics education and related fields.

Recent data indicate that women's participation rates in conferences and mathematics workshops remain lower than their proportion in academic departments, especially at the junior ranks. By providing grants that draw women's attention to the benefits of sharing their knowledge and communicating their results, AWM is intervening positively to increase the role of women in the profession. Reports by an independent evaluator have confirmed that this program is reaching its target group of women with excellent training and serious research potential who do not have consistent access to resources enabling them to attend mathematics meetings. In addition, the mentoring grants have succeeded in starting many of the junior women participants in fresh new research directions and have broadened their view of mathematical research careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Travel and Mentoring Grants Program for women in the mathematical sciences is funded by the National Science Foundation and administered by the Association for Women in Mathematics (AWM). This program began in the 1990's and over the past two decades has enabled several hundred women mathematicians working in the US to attend and speak in conferences in the US and around the world. Some of the motivation for starting this program was that academic women mathematicians who want to build research careers face more obstacles than their male counterparts. Relatively more women than men are employed at small universities and colleges, where there is less funding for travel, and often greater expectations for teaching and service. In addition, women starting their research careers are often also starting their families, and travel is less convenient for them; hence the opportunity to win an award is an incentive that may persuade them to go to a meeting and join the research community.

When this program began, data showed that women were not represented at conferences and workshops, either as speakers or attendees, in proportion to their participation in research, and a second objective of the program was to make women more visible at research meetings. The objective here is to enable more women to serve as role models, and to emphasize to the community women's presence in research and scholarship. Thus, there are two emphases in the Travel Grants Program: doing good for the individual women who obtain grants through the program, and helping to make the mathematical research enterprise more inclusive.

 Over the lifetime of this program, we have made progress in both these objectives. A good proportion of the women who are now leaders in research mathematics have been beneficiaries of these grants, and many have returned to help administer them. And the presence of women at research conferences, though still below the ideal level, is now much more robust. Although many other factors have contributed to this, but the NSF/AWM travel grants have definitely had an impact.

Since its inception, the program has evolved; as it began to have an impact, more components have been added. This grant featured, besides travel grants to research conferences, with an outlay of about $1,500 per grant, a number of "mentoring grants" (about six per year), which provide living expenses for women to make extended visits to research mentors. In addition, the program has supported making connections between mathematics researchers and research in mathematics education by funding researchers in either of these areas to participate in conferences in the other area. This effort aims to improve the quality of mathematics education (at all levels) by connecting educators and researchers.
